description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Reckoning with and repairing the harm caused to communities and making the investments that people need","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 13: Rebalance spending priorities by investing in communities

pageListingInfo.title: Invest in people and communities first

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must invest our resources in community-based supports that prioritize true public safety and help communities thrive. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Invest in people and communities first

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In the United States, we spend an estimated $182 billion annually on our system of mass incarceration even while we dramatically underinvest in the education, health, housing, environmental justice, and other needs that people have.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These misplaced spending priorities do not advance public safety. Indeed, they prevent far too many communities — especially Black, Brown, Indigenous, low-income, and other communities that have experienced systemic disinvestment — from accessing the basic resources that actually keep families safe.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must build a world in which our resources are invested in jobs, physical and mental health treatment, social supports, affordable housing, and all the other community-based programs that both help communities to stay safe and to thrive. A world that invests in art, music, housing, health, and basic needs is a world that prioritizes true public safety.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In the United States, we spend an estimated $182 billion annually on our system of mass incarceration even while we dramatically underinvest in the education, health, housing, environmental justice, and other needs that people have.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Prioritize, as part of a broader, deep, community-led reimagining of what “safety” is, investments that provide basic safety and security to all people (i.e., investments in neighborhood safety, access to health care, quality education, access to housing, a clean and safe environment, and others). ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Support statutory, funding, and administrative policy changes that invest in communities harmed by mass incarceration and incentivize shifts at the federal, state, and local levels to reallocate resources to programs devoted to decarceration, health care, and well-being, rather than those that encourage mass criminalization and incarceration.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Invest in violence prevention and non-carceral crisis response

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must invest in supports that prevent harm in the first place and promote a non-carceral, health-centered response to people who are experiencing crisis. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must imagine a new system, one built around true safety, accountability, and healing, where cycles of harm can be stopped instead of perpetuated.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

subPages.title: Plank 14: Invest in harm prevention and alternative crisis response

pageListingInfo.title: Harm prevention and alternative crisis response

description.raw:
{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must invest in supports that prevent harm in the first place and promote a non-carceral, health-centered response to people who are experiencing crisis. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"





","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Invest in violence prevention and non-carceral crisis response

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Communities will be safest when we prevent harms ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"before ","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"they arise. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"And yet, we balance our spending so that our dollars disproportionately go to incarceration, surveillance, and other carceral approaches that often undermine safety goals. This prioritization must change; we must begin investing in violence interruption, unarmed crisis response, safe passage to school programs, mentorship, streetlights, and the many other non-carceral, non-punitive programs that actually keep families and communities safe.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Instead of a system in which police are the default response to all emergencies, we must build a system in which non-carceral, health-centered first responders offer assistance without further endangering community members or the person who is experiencing crisis. Moreover, we must invest in the non-carceral, community-based services and supports that prevent harm in the first place: well-paying employment, mental and physical health care, and affordable housing, to name a few. Only then can we reduce the overall incidence of harm and embrace genuine safety for all people.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Communities will be safer when we invest in preventing harm ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"before","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" it arises.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Create a Community Public Safety Agency within the state Department of Health and Human Services devoted to implementing various non-carceral, non-punitive grants and other programs that support harm reduction and prevention.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Create a new grant that provides sustainable funding for community-based organizations — especially organizations run by people who are directly impacted and who represent the racial diversity of the community served — that provide non-carceral, prevention-oriented services and interventions.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must imagine a new system, one built around true safety, accountability, and healing, where cycles of harm can be stopped instead of perpetuated.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

promo2.title: Reimagine reentry to promote dignity and safety for all

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must eliminate the barriers that people reentering society face and provide the holistic, community-based services and tools they need to thrive. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 15: Repair harm and support survivors

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must imagine a new system, one built around true safety, accountability, and healing where cycles of harm can be stopped instead of perpetuated.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Plank 15: Rebuild communities and support survivors

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must build a new system - one that promotes true safety and healing. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The carceral system seeks only to punish. It destabilizes communities by tearing families apart with no room for healing, accountability, and growth. The current system of police, prosecution, incarceration, and surveillance does not ensure real accountability and healing for survivors. Instead, it causes more pain to survivors and those who caused harm.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must expand proven, non-carceral models of accountability, such as healing justice, peacemaking circles, and conflict resolution programs — while ensuring that these programs remain defined and led by community members. These accountability practices help individuals and communities process, account for, and heal from violence and other incidents that have caused harm without relying on police and jails. We must also fund the holistic services and supports that survivors need to secure their safety — reparations for harm, vouchers for safe housing, and other community-based supports. Only with these policy changes will we live in a world in which cycles of harm can be stopped instead of perpetuated.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Expand proven, non-carceral models of accountability, such as restorative justice, transformative justice, healing justice, peacemaking circles, and conflict resolution programs — while ensuring that these programs remain defined and led by community members.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Create programs that incentivize police and prosecution offices to dismiss, if not decline to charge, certain misdemeanors and felonies, including juvenile cases. Instead, connect people to non-carceral and non-punitive accountability programming, including programming administered by survivors, LGBTQIA+ people, and/or Black, Indigenous, and other people of color-led community organizations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Eliminate any requirements that a victim cooperate with an investigation or prosecution in order to be eligible for any support and resources.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Reimagine reentry to promote dignity and safety for all

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must eliminate the barriers that people reentering society face and provide the holistic, community-based services and tools they need to thrive. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must offer schools a holistic, relationship-focused way to address conflict and build opportunities for students to improve all children’s chances for success.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must eliminate the barriers that people reentering society face and provide the holistic, community-based services and tools they need to thrive. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Reimagine reentry to promote dignity and safety for all

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Every year, more than 600,000 people return home from prison and approximately 9 million leave local jails. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Disproportionately Black, Brown, and low-income, these individuals face extraordinary barriers to success. Not only have they been removed from their families and communities for months or years, they are often barred from housing, employment and licensure, food, living, and education supports. When these resources are available, they require individuals to navigate the administrative, logistical, and digital complexities of various programs instead of having one holistic source of support. These barriers make it exceedingly difficult for returning citizens to thrive following a period of incarceration.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must provide returning citizens the holistic, community-based services and tools they need to thrive. We must eliminate the specific barriers that people reentering society face, including employment discrimination, family separation, lack of education and training, barriers to obtaining occupational licenses, bans on participating in social programs and public housing, inadequate access to medical care, and restrictions on voting. This will enable communities to grow stronger and heal from the devastation of mass incarceration.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Every year, more than 600,000 people return home from prison and approximately 9 million leave local jails. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Eliminate the specific barriers that people reentering society face, including employment discrimination, family separation, lack of education and training, barriers to obtaining occupational licenses, bans on participating in social programs and public housing, inadequate access to medical care, and restrictions on voting. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Develop pathways to successful reintegration into society for people with arrest and conviction records through apprenticeships, fellowships, and other community-based free social programs and supports.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must offer schools a holistic, relationship-focused way to address conflict and build opportunities for students to improve all children’s chances for success.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must repair the enormous damage that policies from the War on Drugs have caused, while reinvesting all savings into communities.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must offer schools a holistic, relationship-focused way to address conflict and build opportunities for students to improve all children’s chances for success.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The school-to-prison pipeline has become a front door into the criminal-legal system. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"This pipeline is characterized by punitive and exclusionary policies and practices that push students out of school and into the criminal-legal system. School-based officers arrest students on site, put them in chokeholds, and handcuff children as young as six years old. Typical adolescent behavior has become criminalized in school, especially for students of color. For instance, Black students are expelled at three times the rate of White students. Students who are suspended or dispelled for discretionary violations are nearly three times as likely to be involved in the criminal-legal system the following year. This approach funnels youth into jails and prisons and denies them the very opportunities for learning and growth that schools are meant to provide.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The school-to-prison pipeline must end. We must advocate against school-based officers and out-of-school suspensions. But that is not enough. The real solution must go beyond these reactive measures; it must also offer schools a holistic, relationship-focused way to address conflicts that occur and build additional opportunities for students to grow and thrive. Providing these supports will not only end the school-to-prison pipeline but will also create a school-to-opportunity pipeline that improves all children’s chances for success.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Black students are expelled at three times the rate of White students. Students that are suspended or dispelled for discretionary violations are nearly three times as likely to be involved in the criminal legal system the following year. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"End the school-to-prison pipeline by advocating against school-based police officers and out-of-school suspensions, and instead fund counselors and implement trauma-informed care within school systems. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Adequately fund and implement robust restorative justice practices in schools. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must repair the enormous damage that policies from the War on Drugs have caused, while reinvesting all savings into communities.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

promo2.title: Invest in people and communities first

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must invest our resources in community-based supports that prioritize true public safety and help communities thrive.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 18: End the War on Drugs

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must repair the enormous damage caused by the War on Drugs while\ninvesting in the communities that were harmed most.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"June 2021 marked the 50th anniversary of the so-called War on Drugs. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"This effort, which included massive increases in police budgets and the enactment of mandatory minimum sentences, has cost the country a combined $1 trillion and devastated countless communities — especially Black, Brown, Native, and low-income communities that were already subject to disproportionate policing practices and underinvestment. Despite similar usage rates, Black people are approximately four times as likely to be arrested for marijuana possession than White people. Nearly 80 percent of people in federal prison and almost 60 percent of people in state prison for drug offenses are Black or Latino.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Instead of providing treatment and support to address substance use, we use ever-increasing punishments. We must end the War on Drugs and begin repairing the enormous damage that these policies have caused, while reinvesting all savings into the communities most devastated by the War on Drugs. And we must build a world in which addiction is not treated as a crime, but as the public health challenge that it is.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"More than 50 years later, the War on Drugs has done little to eliminate the sale and use of illicit drugs, wasting over $1 trillion in taxpayer money while fueling the incarceration of Black and Brown people.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"End the War on Drugs and treat the sale and use of drugs as the public health crisis that it is. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Decriminalize marijuana, remove criminal penalties for drug possession and certain trafficking offenses that - over the last 50 years - have caused an explosion in the incarcerated population, and repair the harm caused by this failed war through resentencing, sealing and expunging of records, and direct investments into communities.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]}]}

leftText.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Get involved in Vision for Justice and join the movement to reimagine safety in America!","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

rightText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Explore our voting resources and learn how you can help transform the system when we vote for justice.\n","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}
